title: The RBA cannot lose control of the inflation narrative
text:
On the plus side, lower rates mean the Aussie dollar is lower than it otherwise would be. And this year’s house price recovery, partially sparked by cheaper borrowing costs, is “driving a modest turn in spending plans” as the “negative wealth effect weighing on the consumer” eases, says CBA chief economist Michael Blythe.

Meanwhile, the RBA’s trimmed mean measure of inflation – its preferred underlying gauge of consumer price moves – fell below the bottom of the 2-3 per cent target range at the start of 2016 and has remained there since.

Consumer prices grew by 1.6 per cent over the year to June 30, and data for the September quarter, to be released on Wednesday, is expected to show a slight tick higher to 1.7 per cent, according to Bloomberg's survey of forecasts.

The trimmed mean should stay steady at 1.6 per cent over the year to September. But, if anything, the risks are that it comes in lower rather than higher. And nobody is talking about a an imminent return of price pressures.

"We find it hard to envisage core inflation breaking higher any time soon, let alone returning to the mid-point [of the band],'' Westpac economists say.

Indeed, the central bank expects inflation to remain below target until mid-2021, despite the market pricing in another rate cut - to 0.5 per cent - by May next year.

To get inflation moving again, the Reserve Bank has made it clear it wants the unemployment rate, which sits at 5.2 per cent, to drop to 4.5 per cent. This is the point at which wage pressures should begin to build, reckons the central bank.

Unfortunately, there are other forces at work which are set to frustrate this goal.

Advertisement

The sharp fall in residential building is leading to labour retrenchment in a construction industry which employs 9 per cent of the national workforce. That is having knock-on effects to employment in other corners of the economy, ANZ senior economist Catherine Birch says.

So ever easier monetary policy easing appears to have little capacity to lift consumption, business investment, unemployment, or wages. Indeed, it may even have a negative effect.

If rate cuts can't move the dial on these factors, then monetary policy simply cannot hope to get inflation back within the band for the foreseeable future.

So why keep cutting? Why publicly contemplate QE? If monetary policy can't push inflation higher, then why not move the target band to 1-2 per cent and cry "mission accomplished"?

It might seem counterintuitive, but right now might be the worst time to abandon the inflation target.

“Shifting the goal posts [of monetary policy] could … entrench a low inflation mindset,” the RBA governor said in July.

The Reserve Bank is firmly focused on ensuring expectations do not become so unanchored that individuals and companies begin to expect disinflation or even deflation.

Expecting lower consumer prices is damaging to growth as households postpone spending in anticipation of lower prices. This can lead to a further leg lower in overall economic growth and wages, creating a vicious cycle.

Lowe is engaged in a battle for hearts and minds. He needs to keep the flame of the inflation target alive until such time that the structural and cyclical forces depressing consumer prices ease.

In the twilight of the central banking gods, monetary policy is reduced to shadow boxing.
description: In the twilight of the central banking gods, monetary policy is reduced to shadow boxing.
